medical_history.history_of_present_illness: The patient, a 21-year-old male, presented with hypercalcemia (15.4 mg/dL) and renal insufficiency (creatinine 2 mg/dL). He had taken excessive vitamin D supplements (3200 IU daily) and consumed 2-3 gallons of milk weekly for 5 years. He experienced episodes of nausea, vomiting, and polyuria during that time. He was hospitalized twice for hypercalcemia and received extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy once. The symptoms had progressed over these years, leading to the eventual diagnosis.
medical_history.past_medical_history: The patient had a history of nephrolithiasis and hypercalcemia but no prior history of consanguinity or infantile hypercalcemia. He had been hospitalized twice for hypercalcemia and underwent one lithotripsy procedure.
medical_history.family_history: The patient's father had a history of nephrolithiasis in his 20s. There was no mention of a similar history in the patient's six siblings.
medical_history.social_history: The patient consumed high amounts of nutritional supplements containing vitamin D and dairy products, which contributed to his hypercalcemia. He stopped taking these supplements and milk one year prior to presentation.
